Chapter 3 Classes of Random Events Let \(\Omega\) (the sample space of all possible outcomes of an experiments) be an arbitrary non-empty set. Its elements, denoted by \(\omega\), will be interpreted as outcomes (results) of some experiment. As usual, we use \(A \cup B\) and \(A \cap B\) to represent the union and the intersection of any two subsets \(A\) and \(B\) of \(\Omega\), respectively. Also, \(A^c\) is the complement of \(A\subset \Omega\). In particular, \(\Omega^c=\theta\), where \(\theta\) is the empty set. Definition 3.1 (Field) The class \(\mathcal{A}\) of subsets of \(\Omega\) is called a field if it contains \(\Omega\) and is closed under the formation of complements and finite unions, that is if: \(\Omega \in \mathcal{A}\); \(A \in \mathcal{A} \Rightarrow A^c \in \mathcal{A}\); \(A_{1}, A_{2}\in\mathcal{A} \Rightarrow A_{1} \cup A_{2} \in \mathcal{A}\). Proposition 3.1 (Definition of a field) The condition 3 of the definition of a field can be replaced by \(A_{1}, A_{2} \in \mathcal{A} \Rightarrow A_{1} \cap A_{2} \in \mathcal{A}\). That means, \(\mathcal{A}\) is closed under finite intersections. Proof. By de Morgan laws, \((A_{1} \cap A_{2})^{c} = A_{1}^{c} \cup A_{2}^{c}\) and \((A_{1} \cup A_{2})^{c} = A_{1}^{c} \cap A_{2}^{c}\). By the condition 2 of the definition of a field, we can get the desired result. Definition 3.2 (Signa-field) The class \(\mathcal{F}\) of subsets of \(\Omega\) is called a \(\sigma\)-field if it is a field and closed under the formation of countable unions, that is if: \(A_{1}, A_{2}, \ldots, \in \mathcal{F} \Rightarrow \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty}A_{n} \in \mathcal{F}\). Proposition 3.2 (Definition of a sigma-field) The condition 4 of the definition of a sigma-field can be replaced by \(A_{1}, A_{2}, \ldots, \in \mathcal{F} \Rightarrow \bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty}A_{n} \in \mathcal{F}\). That means, \(\sigma\)-field \(\mathcal{F}\) is closed under countable intersections. Proof. By de Morgan lawsand condition 2 of the definition of a field, \((\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty}A_{n})^{c}=\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty}A_{n}^{c}\in\mathcal{F}\) and \((\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty}A_{n})^{c}=\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty}A_{n}^{c}\in\mathcal{F}\). So, we can change the condition 4. Usually, \(\mathcal{F}\) is the set of events (subsets of \(\Omega\)) we are allowed to consider. Definition 3.3 (Random events (events)) The elements of any field of \(\sigma\)-field are called random events (or simply, events). Example 3.1 (A class of events which is a field but not a sigma-field) Let \(\Omega = [0, \infty)\) and \(\mathcal{F}_{1}\) be the class of all intervals of the type \([a,b)\) or \([a,\infty)\), where \(0 \leq a < b < \infty\). Let \(\mathcal{F}_{2}\) be the class of all finite sums of intervals of \(\mathcal{F}_{1}\). Then \(\mathcal{F}_{1}\) is not a field, and \(\mathcal{F}_{2}\) is a field but not a \(\sigma\)-field.
